fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of June 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5  | titleBGColor=#3C78B5  | bgColor=#E7F4FA  }

Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Server.

This suggestion is a priority for the Bitbucket development team and is on our roadmap. However due to the agile nature of product development, we're not able to provide a timeline for when it will be resolved.

Product feedback is collected from a number of different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,
Roger Barnes
Product Manager - Bitbucket

{panel}
*Original request description:*
Comments made in the commit are completely separate from those in the pull request. They should show up in the pull request log and in the code for those reviewing the code in the diff rather than commits pane.

This has caused a fair amount of confusion as comments get lost and users need to look in two places for comments and responses.
fields.summary: Link commit comments to pull requests containing those commits

fields.description: If a comment is for a change, once that change is made the comment is obsolete and just clutters the display. It'd be nice to be able to mark it as closed (so that if you look at a previous revision it still shows, but it doesn't show after it's resolved).
fields.summary: Ability to mark a comment as closed

fields.description:
It'd be really useful to create a single review and publish it as an entity rather than publishing lots of small comments as it needlessly generates a lot of mail and sometimes the answer to the raised question will appear further in the code (but a mail has already gone out for it, needlessly annoying the developer in question).

The workflow I'm thinking of is similar to Review Board where you review the code and then publish the review (and the publish step shows all the comments in context so you can see ones that might not make sense any more).
fields.summary: Ability to stage comments in a review and publish as a single item

fields.description:
In Git version control system it is possible to change history (e.g. to remove accidentally added files which are big/confidential/infringing), or completely delete a branch without a trace (e.g. remove already merged or abandoned feature branches) . This can be useful, but may be dangerous.
What if someone does that by accident or with malicious intent? In corporate settings, surprises are usually not a good thing, especially when it comes to data loss/corruption.

Within our corporate environment we have to rely on unmodified history within our PUSHED repositories to be able to repoduce historical situations exactly. 

Wouldn't it be possible for STASH to reject history changes? 

(see: http://blogs.collab.net/teamforge/comparing-git-reflog-with-teamforge-git-history-protection)
fields.summary: History protection / Branch deletion protection

fields.description: In a comment, if a URL is inserted in the comment text and surrounded with parentheses, the closing parenthesis that is just after the last character of the URL is included in the URL generating a bad URL (broken link). This doesn't happen, for example if the character after a URL is a period '.'.
fields.summary: URL surrounded by parentheses and followed by punctuation includes trailing parenthesis in URL

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to compare branches and see a diff prior to doing a pull request.

This feature has been nailed perfect in bitbucket.
fields.summary: Compare and Diff for Branches

fields.description:
In a similar vein to allowing anonymous access to browse repository contents or to clone repositories, this request is for anonymous access to raw files, when appending "?raw" to browse URLs.

My justification for this feature is that we have files stored in a repository that are passed to bash commands as arguments (specific example: rosinstall files). With Gitorious, I can simply give the bash command a "raw" URL to a Gitorious-hosted file as an argument and it works.  With Stash, I have to download the file from the web (or use curl with a username and password in the clear) to grab the file first, and then pass the file to the bash command.  It's a hassle and/or a security concern.
fields.summary: Allow anonymous access to raw files in a repository

fields.description:
We recently had to move a set of JIRA issues to a new JIRA project, which assigned each issue a new ID. All of our commits and pull requests in Stash still have the old project issue ID. 

Generally, this isn't an issue, as JIRA will 302 redirect any requests for an "old" issue to the new issue ID, so most links in Stash to a old issue ID still work as expected.

The only spot (that I can find) where this behavior doesn't work is in the Overview tab of a pull request. There's a JIRA issue link on the right hand side that displays a modal window with some information pulled from the JIRA issue.

When you click on this for a "moved" issue, inside the modal window you see: 

"Can't display issues. Either you don't have access to view them or they don't exist. Please contact your system administrator if you believe this is incorrect."

Is it possible to have this follow redirects as well and show you details from the new JIRA issue ID?
fields.summary: Pull Requests should display JIRA info for "moved" tickets

fields.description:
On large repository (over 2 GB), then you press F in Stash 'Files' tab, then it et JSON from server (~300KB). In this JSON contains 100000 files. And browser became to slow working when you type first symbol of search, or two symbols.
It freezes browser over 1 minute.
fields.summary: Performance degradation on File Search

fields.description: The addition of the "Delete Branch" option is a nice addition. We would also like to see the ability to have the option checked by default for all pull requests.
fields.summary: Ability to Set "Delete Branch" on the Pull Request Merge Dialogue as Enabled By Default

fields.description: Provide an option to copy all existing repository hooks and configuration onto the new fork.
fields.summary: Option to copy repo hooks when forking
The diff view does not handle CR line endings in files gracefully

fields.description: Currently the source view use a detection mode for line endings -- using the first line ending found as the canonical line ending and stripping others. The diff view however lets git itself decide on the correct line endings to use which can result in different line endings than the source view.
fields.summary: The source and diff views for files should show line endings in the same way

fields.description:
Right now, there is no way to get to a related pull request (which we use for code reviews) from an issue, even though you can get to an issue from a pull request.

It would be nice to jump directly to a related pull request from the source or reviews tab in JIRA.
fields.summary: Ability to see related pull requests from within JIRA
Making a pull request, updating after review comme...

fields.description: The background of the area around the conflict message should be grey to match the file content background, but is white.
fields.summary: Suggestion: File conflict header background should be grey when viewing Unified diff with missing context at top

fields.description:
The Crowd SSO plugin will only enable SSO integration when it can. It tests:

* whether a User Directory has been set up pointing to Crowd.
* whether the remote Crowd has got a valid SSO cookie configuration.

The second test is causing problems because an empty cookie domain is a valid configuration, but the Crowd SSO plugin does consider it valid.

A workaround for now is to configure the SSO Domain in Crowd (Under Admin > General). Note that by configuring the SSO Domain in Crowd, SSO integration will only work when you access the applications over that domain. Make sure you don't set it to localhost, or all Crowd SSO integration will only work when you access the applications through localhost.
fields.summary: Crowd SSO integration is not enabled if Crowd has an empty SSO domain configuration

fields.description:
I would like to point out a need that I have found while performing reviews via stash. A similar need exists when using Crucible as well, but I want to specifically address it as it relates to Stash.

The typical workflow for reviewing a pull request in Stash is this.
- Engineer submits a pull request
- Reviewer looks at the diff and adds comments
- Engineer looks at comments and makes changes
- Engineer pushes their changes
- Reviewer looks at the global diff in stash and reviews the code again

This process repeats itself until the reviewer is happy with the diff in stash, at which point they can approve and accept the pull request.

The problem with this workflow is that as reviews get larger, and as the number of iterations grow more numerous, that the burden is on the reviewer to make sure their comments and concerns were addressed by subsequent commits. Because the diff in stash encompasses the entire pull request, or the diff between that branch and the target branch, there is no way to see iterative diffs alongside the comment view. That basically means that the reviewer has two options for how to re-review the changes once the engineer commits again:

1) Treat the latest commit as a new pull request and re-review the entire set of changes. The benefit of this is supreme confidence that high quality code will make it into master. The downside is this greatly increases the amount of time that the reviewer must spend reviewing code because they are forced to also re-review code that they implicitly "green-lighted" on the previous review by not commenting on.

2) Use a combination of the Overview activity list to map their comments to the individual commit diff for each new commit since their last review. The individual commit diffs do show the iterative progress that the reviewer needs to see so that they know what new changes were made. But those diffs do not include comments, so they also need to review their own comments in a separate window to remind them of the context of the changes and the rest of the pull request.

Neither of these two things are major issues for small, targeted pull requests.  I'll concede, for the sake of argument, that small, targeted, pull requests are ideal and a best practice.  But I think we can still agree that this doesn't always happen, and I think the tool can support a broader and more complete workflow by improving the user experience for the scenario I describe above.

So, here's my proposed solution. I think the tool should support one or both of the following features:

1) On the Diff view in a pull request, allow the user to view either the global pull request diff, from first commit to last commit, or specify specific revisions to view the diff from and to. That will keep the Diff view as the single source of truth, while also improving the review workflow for iterative reviews.

2) When the user clicks on a commit link from the pull request overview activity list, instead of taking the user to view the diff for that commit in isolation, pull in the comments to also show those there.

I am really interested to hear what the Stash team thinks about this proposed change. While we like Stash, and we see it as an improvement to Crucible for our workflow, I think these changes would take it to a whole new level for us by streamlining the iterative code review workflow for when a review takes several iterations to get right.

Thanks,

- Conrad
fields.summary: As a reviewer, I want to use comments and diffs on a pull request to clearly track iterative changes made during the review of a pull request.

fields.description: In our workflow we need to disable ability to delete branches on merge.
fields.summary: Ability to deny branch deletion per repository on Pull Requests merging

fields.description: The "Generate a Stash plugin using the Atlassian SDK" section is missing the invocation of the "atlas-create-stash-plugin-module" tool.  Without invoking that tool, the boilerplate that the next sections instructs us to delete does not exist.
fields.summary: Improve the "Generate a Stash plugin using the Atlassian SDK" in the developer documentation

fields.description:
This page shows a decent chart of the notifications that Stash sends: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Notifications

We'd love to be able to configure what notifications get sent and to whom at the administration level.

For instance, we don't want developers to be spammed with emails every time a reviewer adds a comment to a pull request, but rather only at the end when it is approved or rejected.
fields.summary: Add Configuration Options for Pull Request Notifications

fields.description:
As a developer,
I want to see when my branch forked from another
So that I can quickly see which commits have been incorporated into a branch I am working on with colleagues


The following screenshot shows a possible idea on how to represent this, by simply showing a line border between the first commit to the new branch, away from the previous.

!Selection_540.png!
fields.summary: As a developer I want to see when my branch forked from another

fields.description:
As a commenter,
I want JIRA issues mentioned in pull-request comments to be hot-linked,
So that when I am discussing a particular pull-request, if I mention a ticket it can be easily observed by other members of the team viewing the discussing.

Scenarios:

 * "Yeah, that looks like a bug, I've raised TICKET-100 to fix this going forward, but for now we can go ahead and merge"
 * "I'm not happy with this change, TICKET-120 will be much harder to complete"

Possible progression for delivery;

# Initial lightweight integration where Stash simply recognises issue keys and links to the JIRA instance associated with the project/repo
# Slightly tighter integration using a similar UI to the issue view on the pull request (ie pop-in window frame) to show a summary without hopping to JIRA
# Bidirectional integration where JIRA gets a trackback reference, and the stash ui includes the mentions as if they were mentions in commit messages
fields.summary: As a commenter I want JIRA issues mentioned in comments to be hot-linked

fields.description:
I have multiple groups contributing to one repository. Each group has its own prefix of branches while the core developers contribute to branches with no prefixes.

For example, the core developers use a branch named "test", while another group happened to create a branch named "foo/test".

Setting the default branch for the repository to be "test", when a new user cloned the repository, the default branch which ends up on the user's machine is the branch "foo/test", instead of the desired branch "test". 

It appears to just be looking at the suffix of the ref, instead of the full ref beneath refs/heads. Since "foo/test" sorts before "test", the user receives "foo/test" when clone'ing the repository.

The "Files" tab in the gui does display the correct branch "test".
fields.summary: Default branch for repository can return incorrect default branch on clone
there's a bug in the upload project avatar dialog....

fields.description:
This is due to the fact that we use our streaming API (and paginate it in Java) when there is a since parameter but use the Paged API when there isn't. We need to modify {{com.atlassian.stash.rest.pull.JsonChangesetCallback}} so that it passes back a {{nextPageStart}}

Raised from https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/151325/why-is-islastpage-false-but-no-nextpagestart
fields.summary: Inconsistent behaviour for nextPageStart attribute on commits REST resource when specifying a since parameter

fields.description:
In the documentation https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Using+pull+requests+in+Stash#UsingpullrequestsinStash-Discussingapullrequest, it is mentioned that "Participants can commit new changes to the branch. Stash auto-updates the Commits tab of the pull request, so you can see exactly which commits will be merged"

But this feature doesn't work in version 2.1.2.
fields.summary: No auto-updates of the commits tab of the pull request

fields.description:
Currently Stash forces diffs (as used in pull requests) to include copies. Unfortunately this cannot be overridden by a local configuration value. Git defaults to 50% similarity of files, which in some cases can identify incorrect copies and renames which can be confusing.

It would be nice to configure the exact behaviour and thresholds that Stash uses.
fields.summary: Make rename/copy thresholds in git diff configurable
Coffee. Poker. Stash.

fields.description:
Currently Stash has the infrastructure for plugin developers to write a java plugin which pings remote URLs. Often this can be too time consuming or is not an option for repository admins who don't have system admin access to install the plugin.

Providing generic web hooks with predefined POST json data these repository admins could write services using their favourite language without the need to know Java or be able to install a plugin
fields.summary: Provide web hooks for Repository change events

fields.description:
Currently the only way to get commit information into the activity stream is by using the FishEye stream.

Given that Stash provides this same information, with a DVCS friendly interface, it would be great to channel users to the Stash interface rather than FishEye for browsing.
fields.summary: The Dashboard Activity Stream should include Stash as an available stream

fields.description: This shouldn't be a problem if SSO or remember me tokens are used iff the session only contains authentication information.
fields.summary: Address session state

fields.description: Scheduling tasks need to be either suspended in the standby instance or we could use the [clustering feature|http://quartz-scheduler.org/documentation/quartz-2.x/configuration/ConfigJDBCJobStoreClustering] of Quartz.
fields.summary: Address scheduling tasks

fields.description: It should be possible to configure Stash to disable the locking of the home directory (this should still be the default though).
fields.summary: Enable the home directory to be shared by multiple instances

fields.description:
State that is stored in the database and read once on startup and then kept in memory needs to be reinitialised on demand (e.g. based on an event).

E.g.

   * Queues for pull request re-scope
   * Queues for comment drifts calculations
fields.summary: Reinitialise in-memory state based on the persistent settings

fields.description:
Many SSO solutions integrate at the Tomcat layer by passing an authenticated user(name) to Tomcat. Inside the web application, this username is available through {{HttpServletRequest.getRemoteUser()}} and {{HttpServletRequest.getRemotePrincipal()}}. 

Stash should accept this username as already authenticated and transparently log the user in with that username.

Presumably, the SSO solution provides an external login page. Stash should redirect the user to a configurable login URL when authentication is required.

Likewise, when the user logs out in Stash, the SSO session should be terminated. The logout success URL should be configurable as well.

Finally, when a user has been authenticated using container managed authentication and the remoteUser name is no longer provided by the container, the user should be logged out of Stash.

Questions:
* Are the login and logout URLs optional or required? 
* Can the Remote User be spoofed through HTTP headers? Most SSO integrations seem to rely on the AJP connector and not use the HTTP connector. Not sure whether that is for security reasons. 
* Can container managed authentication support be enabled out of the box, or should it be explicitly enabled by sysadmins? Related to the previous questions.
fields.summary: Support container managed authentication

fields.description: It should be possible to run Stash in an environment that allows for hot standbys/failover.
fields.summary: High availability/failover

fields.description:
I don't know why, but recently I've encountered problems with TortoiseGit and Stash. I'm trying to clone repository. I choose private key (properly configured in Stash) for that repo and I got No authentication method supported (server sent: publickey). When I change ssh client from PLink.exe (Windows) to ssh shipped with MsysGit and configure ssh keys under ".ssh" it's working properly.

Everything worked like a charm when I was testing Stash on my virtual machine etc, but right now, when I configured production: Stash + MySQL + Apache as proxy, I have this strange bug. I don't know if it's TortoiseGit fault or Stash.

Any ideas?
fields.summary: TortoiseGit (Putty SSH client) and public key authentication.

fields.summary: Need editable labels for SSH keys

fields.description: Like the Markdown support, my {{README.md}} file looks great. Except for the tables. I become used to creating tables in [GitHub Flavored Markdown|https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/wiki/Markdown-Cheatsheet#wiki-tables]. Would love to see it in Stash Markdown.
fields.summary: Add Table Support to Markdown
JIRA indexing does not pick up commits for a couple of hours.

fields.description:
It would be great if you could wrap your diff output implementation in a method that could be overridden in a plugin.  It could be as simple as a method that has two parameters to represent the before and after files and a string return value that represents the HTML to display.

In our case, we'd like to use the command line driven report output available in BeyondCompare.  It provides tons of configuration options and our reviewers are very familiar with the appearance of the output.

We'd want this customization to apply to all diffs in the system--history comparisons, commit file list, pull request diff, etc.  

I appreciate that a built-in side-by-side or configurable diff is a feature Atlassian isn't prioritizing at the moment.  However, what I've requested above would allow clients that want an improved output to put forth some effort immediately to achieve what we want.
fields.summary: Allow custom diff implementation
Lowercase the project key in the clone url

fields.description: At the moment if I want to respond to a comment mention, I have to listen to the onComment event and look for a tag myself.  Since the notifications plugin already does this work, it would be handy to have it fire a specific event for mentions instead.  Then I wouldn't have to use my own regex to look for mentions or anything like that, removing myself from implementation details.
fields.summary: I would like an event to be fired when a user is mentioned in a comment

fields.description: Starting Stash using bin\start-stash.bat works as I have configured it to, listening on both 7990 (HTTP) and 8443 (HTTPS).  However, after running bin\service.bat install and starting the service, Stash is only accessible over port 7990 (HTTP).  netstat reveals that port 8443 is unused.
fields.summary: Running STASH as a Windows Service fails to start listening over HTTPS (8443)

fields.description: It would be nice to have the possibility to reset the Captcha for each user via Stash administration.
fields.summary: Reset User Captcha From Administration

fields.description: Will be nice to view "Can't Merge" bulb warning icon in list of Pull Requests near by Approves.
fields.summary: Show "Can't Merge" icon in Pull Request list

fields.description: In Pull Request lists for Repo now shown only approves, will be nice to show build status too.
fields.summary: Show build status in Pull Requests list

fields.description:
We currently have many repos (20+) and growing (likely to about 100 after we finish migrating our projects out of CVS).

When we have an issue that spans many projects, we create a branch for that issue, fix it, and assign a Pull Request to the developer who is currently working on that particular project.

If people haven't merged these Pull Requests after a certain amount of time we want to be able to walk over to their desk and give them a poke!  The problem is, it's currently a real pain to figure out what pull requests have not been merged, since it would mean clicking into each repo individually and checking their pull request status.

Ideally, it would be nice if the "Pull Request Inbox" would also show Pull Requests that I have created that have yet to be merged or declined.

I saw a similar feature request that talked about creating an entire dashboard for this sort of thing, but for us that would be overkill.  We really just need one place where we can see the status of Pull Requests we have created.  The Pull Request Inbox seems like the perfect place for this.
fields.summary: Show Pull Requests you have created in the Pull Request Inbox.

fields.description:
In other words, as a Stash administrator, I'd like other users to be able to create new repositories, but at the same time minimize the possibility that they forget about or screw up the EOL handling.

Suggested approach:
* Allow the admin to edit default .gitattributes (providing a good catch-all default with Stash distribution would be a bonus!)
* On a Create Repository page, add a checkbox "commit default .gitattributes to master" - which would do exactly that if turned on (the default)

Note that a checkbox is needed because sometimes the creator might want a completely empty new repository - for example, to run SVN importer.

I wonder if this can be implemented with a plugin
fields.summary: As a Stash administrator, I'd like to provide the default .gitattributes file for all repositories

fields.description:
https://developer.atlassian.com/stash/docs/latest/how-tos/updating-build-status-for-commits.html

Now all Canceled on TeamCity builds marked as Failed. The quick solution is report canceled builds as Success (for ability to not affect on Pull Request merge requirement), but it wrong state.
fields.summary: Add 'Canceled' state for Build Statuses

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Data Center.

We spend a significant amount of time determining our product investments in Bitbucket Data Center. Unfortunately, we are not planning to address this suggestion in the next 12 months. In the last year, we have resolved many of the highly voted suggestions like Reviewer groups, Pull request templates, capability to enable/disable source branch deletion on merging pull requests and our upcoming roadmap includes a number of other top voted suggestions, including repository archiving. Please check out our [public roadmap|https://www.atlassian.com/roadmap/data-center?product=bitbucket] for more details on the coming soon and future items.

I understand that this may be disappointing, but it’s important for us to be open, honest, and transparent with our customers. Product feedback is collected from many different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,

Imran Khan

Product Manager - Bitbucket Data Center & Server
{panel}
*Original request description*

If pull request was approved and merged by wrong decision then we need to rollback it and re-open Pull Request. To do this git has full support:
[http://git-scm.com/2010/03/02/undoing-merges.html]
You should used {{git revert -m 1 <hash>}}
After this Stash can automatically reopen Pull Request from receive hook. And work with Pull Request as it has not been merged yet. Then merge it again and all be fine from Git side.
fields.summary: Ability to Revert merged Pull Request and Re-open it

fields.description:
*Update Aug 2018* - This was released in [Bitbucket Server/Data Center 5.13|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-5-13-release-notes-953131455.html]

Original description below:

With the fixed hierarchy of only two layers (Projects-Repositories) proper categorisation of repositories can become cumbersome.

This can greatly alleviate this in large organisations with many repositories.
 Tags or Labels here are the same concept as "Labels" in Jira. This is not tags as in `git tag…`

In our use case, some things tags would be used for is specifying:
 - development teams involved and/or responsible for a repository,
 - primary technologies involved,
 - primary systems components involved,
 - status flags, etc
fields.summary: Labeling of repositories

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of September 2018|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Server.

This suggestion is a priority for the Bitbucket development team and is on our roadmap, however we're not able to provide a timeline for when it will be resolved. [Learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,
Anton Genkin

Product Manager - Bitbucket Server
{panel}
*Original request description*

On project pages, where all repositories within that project are listed, there is no description column (like there is a description column for each project on the frontpage of Stash).

With the fixed hierarchy of only two layers (Projects-Repositories) proper categorisation of repositories can become cumbersome, and providing descriptions against the listing of repositories would help significantly.

README files within each repository does not suffice.
fields.summary: Description for repositories
Nice, finally, manage git hooks!

fields.description: We use pull requests extensively for connecting the written code to the feature requests. It is really useful to be able to reopen a merged pull request, for example when you notice a bug/omission in the feature after merging. Rejected pull requests _can_ be reopened, but merged ones can't.
fields.summary: Allow opening of merged pull requests for additional commits

fields.description:
I'd like to see a way for read-only observers of a repository to be able to clone the repository, make code changes, and submit a pull request for those changes.

In Github, the workflow would be to fork the repository, then push a new branch, and submit a pull request from that fork.

It would be nice to see another way to contribute without the overhead of a fork.  One way may be to allow observers to push branches called "pullrequest/name". Pull requests could be created from those branches but they wouldn't have access to any other branch.

Another option would be to accept a Git Patch as a pull request. Rather than requiring a branch to merge, submitting a patch file against a branch could create a pull request.
fields.summary: Allow read-only observers to contribute to a repository using only pull requests

fields.description:
Installing Stash 2.2.0, the application doesn't run if there are spaces in the installation directory path:
{code}
C:\Program Files\Stash\bin>start-stash.bat
To run STASH in the foreground, start the server with start-stash.bat /fg
.


Using STASH_HOME:      "C:\Users\ssetayeshfar\stash-home"
Using CATALINA_BASE:   "C:\Program Files\Stash"
Using CATALINA_HOME:   "C:\Program Files\Stash"
Using CATALINA_TMPDIR: "C:\Program Files\Stash\temp"
Using JRE_HOME:        "C:\Users\devtools\Java\jdk1.7.0_17"
Using CLASSPATH:       "C:\Program Files\Stash\bin\bootstrap.jar;C:\Program Files\
.
The system cannot find the file C:\Program.

Started Atlassian Stash at:
http://localhost:/

If you encounter issues starting or stopping Atlassian Stash, please see the Troub
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Installation+Troubleshooting+Guide
{code}
When I moved the installation folder to a different path with no spaces I was able to launch it successfully.
The installation manual indicates that there should not be any spaces in the <stash-home> path, but nothing is mentioned about the installation path. (InstallStashOnWindowsManual.JPG)
fields.summary: Can not run Stash if there are spaces in the installation directory

fields.description:
*Web Links:*
* FEDS - Directory Scanning Plugin - https://marketplace.atlassian.com/30318

*Crucible Administrator's desire new Stash repositories to be automatically seen and added to Crucible (or to <insert atlassian product here>) on repo creation.* One attempt to facilitate this using Crucible with the Directory Scanning Plugin (FEDS) installed had the following problem:
FEDS was configured to scan the Stash $STASH_HOME sub-directory data/repositories/ for new repositories. When repos are added to Stash the following things happen (among others)
# a record is created in the database table 'repository'
# a clone is created in the $STASH_HOME/data/repositories directory using the new db record's primary key as the directory name

FEDS added each repo it found in the directory to Crucible - but without any useful identifying information. Each repo was added using the directory name as the Crucible Repo name. And Crucible doesn't surface the repo description useful for identifying what repo ## really is.

My thought - if Stash provided a rest call to query repositories based on ID then the FEDS plugin could be modified to use the directory name in a rest call to pull Repository intel out of Stash - that way the Crucible Repo it then creates could have a meaningful name
fields.summary: Enhance REST to allow query by repository ID

fields.description:
_(Not sure if this is a bug or a feature request)_

Since Gravatar uses email address as a unique identifier, obviously changing my email address setting will change my Gravatar.

Currently in the profile page, editing details is a nice inline-edit experience, but it seems odd that while all the fields update immediately, I have to refresh the page to make sure I've got the right Gravatar showing.

I'd like to see the Gravatar update inline when the email address has been changed.
fields.summary: Profile page: Changing my email address should update the Gravatar shown

fields.description: Providing an installer for Stash would give a consistent installation experience for those that install/upgrade JIRA and Confluence.  This would also allow system admins to setup their Stash installation as a service during installation.
fields.summary: Provide an Installer

fields.description:
It would be nice to have something similar to Crucible's time slider within reviews.

Here's an example use case:
  - The author creates a review
  - A reviewer makes some comments
  - The author pushes changes in response to those comments

Now, the reviewer now has trouble seeing just those new changes.  It gets even worse if the author pushed a rebased branch.  The history of the pull request is not the history of the commits on the branch, it is the series of differences between where the branch HEAD has pointed since the creation of the review.
fields.summary: Ability to View Pull Request Branch Modification History

fields.description:
When changing the IP pattern under Incoming Authentication for Trusted Applications, if there already is an IP listed a duplicate key violation is thrown.

Repro:
1. Add an IP pattern under Incoming Authentication and click Apply.
2. Add another IP and click Apply.

Workaround:
Remove all the IP patterns, click Apply. Then add them all at the same time, it now saves properly.

fields.summary: DataIntegrityViolationException when configuring Trusted Application

fields.description:
If build hung up, or network error, Stash will always contains builds in Pull Request in Running state. No way to remove them from it.

This disables Pull Request merging if you enables "Requires for 1 success build" in settings.

Stash must have ping Builds, if no pings from CI for Running state build since last hour, then build may be ignored or removed.
fields.summary: Automatically or Manually remove Running builds from Pull Requests if build is missed

fields.description:
In our command we denied merges into master directly, all thing must be done via Pull Requests. But is Pull Request contains more what 1000 files, Stash not allow to view all of them, only first 1000.

Will be nice to have pager or some onfly tree expander is Pull Request contains really a lot of files.
fields.summary: Ability to review large Pull Requests

fields.description:
After Pull Request received new Commit Stash perform updating of {{refs/pull-request/123/from}}. I don't know why, but this take a time (minutes), if Pull Request contains more what 1000 files.

Will be nice to have 'Pending' status for signaling user, what Stash is currently checking this Pull Request.

Another one point. The {{from}} reference can be updated quickly, but all {{merge}} references still can take a long time.
fields.summary: Show status 'Pending' for Pull Requests

fields.description:
I am on the commit stream of a repo

https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/JIRA/repos/jira/commits

I figure it should auto updated in a long interval say 10 minutes.

Also it should use the standard browser tricks of page.visibility to update itself if I cam back to it.
fields.summary: Have the commits stream on a repo auto update
Allow users to manage (install, disable) and edit old school commit hook scripts

fields.description:
Allowing commits that break builds means the commit history will include commits that represent broken code. CI is much more useful when the CI implements a pre-commit policy which requires the commit to pass a CI (bamboo) build prior to being accepted as a commit. If the CI build fails, the push to Stash should fail with the appropriate error message(s) and the developer should fix their branch and attempt push to Stash with corrected code. Having this capability completely changes developer culture in that developers must be proactive rather than reactive. 

In a feature branch development model, the pre-commit verification would ensure that the feature + baseline builds as a minimum commit requirement. That would be a good starting point. My assumption here is that Bamboo and Stash would work together to enable this functionality. Stash should see the intent to commit and Bamboo should validate pre-commit conditions. Once validated, Stash should accept or reject the commit accordingly.
fields.summary: Implement pre-commit triggers

fields.description: If your README.md file is too large it renders with the message "File content too large to display".  Not really sure why there is a limit here.  See attached.
fields.summary: README markdown doesn't display if "too large"

fields.description:
Documentation:
https://developer.atlassian.com/stash/docs/latest/how-tos/updating-build-status-for-commits.html

TeamCity plugin:
https://github.com/mendhak/teamcity-stash

I need to test Merge Result of Pull Request, so TeamCity monitor references {{refs/pull-requests/*/merge}} in Git and run builds on this commits. After commit TeamCity send Build Status into Stash.

Now Stash commit for reference {{refs/pull-requests/*/merge}} is not a part of Pull Request. But in other hand Stash look into this commit to say that Pull Request can't be merged if conflicts. A little bit misconfiguration.

In fact TeamCity can't not send to Stash 'previous' commit from {{refs/pull-requests/*/merge}}, because it's not guarantied that the build ran on the Automerge commit is also fine on previous commit. It's two totally different commits. So, TeamCity plugin makes the right call for valid commits. But Stash must attach this commit Build Status into Pull Request also as usual commit contains in Pull Request.
See discussion here:
https://github.com/mendhak/teamcity-stash/issues/2
fields.summary: Detect builds on pull request auto-merges in Build Status API and link to them

fields.description:
I'd like to have support for using repository names longer than 64 characters. 

Working with Android source code this limit is reached when adding repositories with names based on their directory structure.

Eg. Since directory structures is not supported in Stash I replaced / with - in the path and imported the repo with this name "platform-prebuilts-gcc-darwin-x86-arm-arm-linux-androideabi-4.7", 64 chars already (the same would be done when using github or gitourious).
Then I wanted to separate our developed code from the standard Android code somehow (since there are at least 350 git repos!) and I thought a good enough structure would be to prefix the android repos with "aosp-", but this was not possible.
fields.summary: Longer repository names

fields.description:
Noticed this twice today. The top right buttons sometimes random use Times New Roman

!https://api.monosnap.com/image/download?id=9ZpG1NXKARXcNZURFzDdYqr9Q!

Refresh page, commenting etc fixes the problem.
fields.summary: Buttons occasionally rendered in Times New Roman

fields.description: Stash created {{refs/notes/pull-request}} note and save conflicts. Will be nice to see this list of conflicted files in special Tab.
fields.summary: If Pull Request conflicted, show conflicted files in different tab

fields.description:
We using crossmerging strategy, then a big one merge commit is commited 'as is' with unresolved conflicted files. Files start contains 'Conflict Markers' as 'Automerge' commit for Stash Pull Request.
Will be nice, if Stash start render not only Automerge commit, but also anyone commit in Pull Request, if it contains conflict markers.
fields.summary: Show files with conflict markers as conflicted

fields.description:
In a previous support request we were given a line for setenv.sh:

{noformat}
JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS="-Dstash.jira.key.pattern=((?<!([A-Z0-9]{1,10})-?)[A-Z0-9]+-\d+)"
{noformat}

This is needed to allow our custom key scheme to be supported in stash (specifically we use project keys including numbers after an initial letter, e.g. C100-1).

Removing the JVM argument from the config file allows Stash to start.
fields.summary: Specifying unquoted stash.jira.key.pattern causes Stash to fail to start

fields.description: The merge button on a pull request does not refresh.  This is most apparent when the merge is blocked by a "required approvers" repository hook.  When the last required approver clicks "Approve" the merge button still shows that the pull request does not have enough approvers.  The user must refresh the screen before the merge button becomes enabled.
fields.summary: Merge button should refresh when pull request is approved

fields.description:
The add hooks dialog on the repository hooks page has a link and a button which both go to https://stash.atlassian.com/plugins/servlet/upm/requests?category=Repository+Hooks

Depending on whether you're and admin or not, you'll get redirected by UPM to https://stash.atlassian.com/plugins/servlet/upm/marketplace/featured?category=Repository+Hooks or https://stash.atlassian.com/plugins/servlet/upm/requests/featured?category=Repository+Hooks which shows the "Staff Picked" hooks.

This is less useful than going to the "Most Popular" hooks, which would show the user the hooks most downloaded by others.
fields.summary: Stash upm/requests links incorrectly default to staff picked

fields.description: Stash currently allows individuals to be added to the list of reviewers. Reviewer groups would be handy when adding the "Performance Team" or "Product Tech Writers" to a review.
fields.summary: Allow groups to be added as reviewers

fields.description: If someone comment Pull Request and someone else push commit to it, then Stash create comment on old lines for old code, but attach it to new code. In result you will see comment attached to wrong lines and it will make crazy someone who start to read comments on diff. Diff is from new commited code, but comment from old commit atached to old commit lines.
fields.summary: Concurrent commits force Stash to create wrong comments in Pull Requests

fields.description:
If I perform an access request to Stash using an invalid password, I don't see anything logged.

This can help also help track rogue build bots using invalid credentials that trigger CAPTCHAs that currently can't be disabled (STASH-3001).

It would be nice to have it in a security log similar to what JIRA offers and log: failed attempts, password changes, SSH key changes, etc.
fields.summary: Provide better logging/audits for failed access attempts
Excessive log warnings with TrustedApps

fields.description: It is not possible to add a web-fragment to the UI that is only available to a particular permission. For example, I added a web-item to the Project Overview page. That link should only be available to project admins. I implemented a Condition class like usual in plugin development. However, the condition is never evaluated and the link is visible to all project members. I also looked for standards Stash Conditions in the JavaDoc but could not find any.
fields.summary: Support web-fragment conditions
Javadoc on PermissionService does not match implementation for hasAnyUserPermission
Create a Windows Installer
Create a Linux installer

fields.description:
This issue is most relevant to the author, as the author rarely has write access. The primary value of a pull request is to allow somebody who does not have write access to the target branch, to request that somebody who does have write access to the target branch "pull" content. The code review aspects are secondary and relate to quality control before completing the "pull".

If branch controls are enabled on the target branch, as is a common requirement for pull requests, the following confusing behaviour occurs for the author, and for any secondary reviewers who themselves do not have write access:

1) A merge button is shown. However, the merge button has a caution icon next to it detailing that "You have insufficient permissions to update 'xxxx'. ...". As the author doesn't expect to be able to merge, this is confusing. It would be strongly preferred for the Merge button to either be clearly disabled or removed altogether.

2) If you browse around the pull request - for example, from "Overview" to "Diff" and back to "Overview", it shows a warning: "This pull request can't be merged. You will need to resolve conflicts to be able to merge." As the author doesn't expect to be able to merge, this is confusing. The "More information" also seems confusing as all it adds is: "You have insufficient permissions to update 'master'. Check your branch permissions with the project administrator."

I consider this a bug as I think the branch access controls are not working properly with pull requests.

I tried to determine whether any special conditions are required to cause this problem and it doesn't seem there are.

Steps to reproduce:

1) Set write restrictions on "master" to only allow user A to write to "master".

2) User B to clone repository and create branch "feature/X" off branch "origin/master". "git clone ...", "git checkout -b feature/X origin/master".

3) User B to make any simple change, commit ("git commit"), push ("git push origin feature/X").

4) User B to create pull request from "feature/X" to "master".

At this point, you will see the Merge button with the caution icon not so helpfully pointing out the lack of permission. If you click on "Diff" then back to "Overview" you will see the not so helpful warning that this pull request can't be merged (which is false).

Our users are most confused about the second behaviour. I consider both behaviours confusing.
fields.summary: Branch access controls cause confusing behaviour for pull request authors and reviewers.

fields.description:
If the files are encoded with non-UTF8 character encoding, the diff view will have invalid character due to git diff using UTF8 encoding.

Need to convert non-UTF8 files to UTF8 before generating the diff view.

**NOTE: This fix was enabled as an _opt-in_ feature. A repository admin must enable "Transcode diff" for non-UT8 files to work. See [this comment|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-3179?focusedCommentId=611578&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-611578] for details.**
fields.summary: Convert non-UTF8 files to UTF8 before generating the diff view
